Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Proposal: Using a Project-Based Learning Approach for Education and Training in Technological Innovation for STEM Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project in the School of Technology at North Carolina A&T State University (NCA&T) seeks to enhance students' knowledge and instruction in technological innovation using a project-based approach. This training program will be integrated as part of the undergraduate and graduate courses in innovation and technology management while preparing students for the Ph.D. program in Technology Management which is offered at NCA&T through a consortium of five other universities. Undergraduate students are involved in the implementation of this project.

The specific objectives of the project are to: create instructional materials for technological innovation in the context of manufacturing and services; incorporate the new content into one new course, one course in the undergraduate applied engineering technology program and one graduate course in the Master of Science in technology management program using project-based learning and case studies; and study the impact of this education and training on students' learning outcomes. Improvements in areas such as higher order cognitive skills, self-efficacy, ease of learning of subject matter, teamwork, and communication skills will be evaluated. The findings of this project will be disseminated and materials will be developed into an instructional package which will be publically available and can be adapted by other institutions to educate and train students in technological innovation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project is to enhance students’ knowledge and learning about technological innovation and entrepreneurship. New content was developed into one new undergraduate course in Applied Engineering Technology, one graduate course in Master of Science in Technology Management and one cross-listed (undergraduate/graduate) course using project-based learning and case studies. The education and training in innovation and entrepreneurship has two components: the theory section and the practice section. The teaching team provides lectures and teaching materials on technological innovation and related topics. The mentoring team, which is mostly innovators, innovation practitioners and serial entrepreneurs, provides coaching and mentoring to the students. The Improvements in students’ learning outcomes (higher order cognitive skills, self-efficacy, ease of learning subject matter, teamwork, and communication skills) have been evaluated. A survey instrument is developed to measures students’ skillsets in technological innovation and entrepreneurship, including risk taking, innovativeness, reactiveness, performance, appearance, social, and decision-making skills. The relationship between student skillsets in entrepreneurship and project performance has been examined through relating students’ entrepreneurship skills to their project performance in multiple courses. The relationship between innovation and risk management has been investigated, and capabilities have been identified that improve both organizational innovation and responsiveness to disruption. Multiple undergraduate and graduate students are involved in the research activities during the tenure of the project. The research findings of this project have been published as peer-reviewed journal articles and conference papers and disseminated through presentations in conferences, meetings and invited talks.

 

The project creates a pipeline of graduate students for the master and PhD programs in Technology Management at NC A&T. The students are able to closely interact with practitioners in the industry and receive their feedback on the potential applications of the technology. This in turn, will enhance the university-industry partnership. This mechanism promotes synergies among key stakeholders involved in the process of innovation, which greatly enhances the technological capability and economic development of the region. Furthermore, because a critical issue in STEM education is how to train and educate students who know how to innovate and translate technologies to market, the broader outcome of this effort would be to educate professionals in a variety of STEM fields who are knowledgeable about the process of innovation, which help empower HBCUs to be leaders in the area of innovation and technology transfer. This in turn, will directly benefit the nation’s pipeline of STEM graduates who are knowledgeable about innovation, which directly benefits the nation’s well-being and economic prosperity.
